title: 111_s3960
content:
The Act is titled the "Tyler Clementi Higher Education Anti-Harassment Act of 2010" and provides information for students regarding institutional and financial assistance. Section 485(f) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include definitions for 'commercial mobile service' and 'electronic communication'. The term 'harassment' in the context of electronic messaging services includes conduct that is severe, persistent, or pervasive enough to limit a student's participation in a higher education program or create a hostile educational environment. In higher education, harassment is defined as conduct that creates a hostile or abusive environment based on a student's race, color, national origin, sex, disability, sexual orientation, gender identity, or religion. Each institution must develop and distribute a report as part of their program participation. The policy regarding harassment in higher education prohibits harassment of enrolled students by other students, faculty, and staff on campus, noncampus buildings, public property, through electronic mail addresses, computers, communication networks, or during sponsored activities. The policy on harassment in higher education includes programs to prevent harassment, procedures for reporting incidents, and institutional actions following reports. It addresses areas such as timely action in cases of alleged harassment and informing both the accuser and accused. The policy on harassment in higher education includes informing the accuser and accused of disciplinary proceedings outcomes, possible sanctions, counseling services, and designating an office for tracking harassment reports. SEC. 3. ANTI-HARASSMENT COMPETITIVE GRANT PROGRAM. In this section, the Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible entities, defined as institutions of higher education or consortia of institutions in the same State, for carrying out anti-harassment activities as per the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary awards grants to eligible entities for anti-harassment activities at higher education institutions. Grants must be sufficient for the purpose and used to address various types of harassment by implementing programs to prevent or provide services for affected students. The Secretary awards grants to eligible entities for anti-harassment activities at higher education institutions. Eligible entities must educate students, faculty, or staff on preventing or addressing harassment. Grants are awarded for up to 3 years, with a possible renewal for an additional 2 years. Selection criteria prioritize entities with the greatest need and potential benefit from the grant. The eligible entity must evaluate the effectiveness of activities funded by the grant in reducing harassment and improving tolerance. A report on the evaluation results must be submitted to the Secretary. Additionally, the Secretary must provide Congress with a report 12 months after receiving the first evaluation report and annually thereafter. The Secretary must report to Congress on the number and types of eligible entities receiving assistance, the anti-harassment programs being implemented, and any other useful information for evaluating the program's effectiveness in reducing harassment at higher education institutions. The Secretary will also publish a best practices report based on the information provided. Authorization of Appropriations: $50,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2013 to 2018 for higher education institutions and interested parties. SEC. 4. EFFECT ON OTHER LAWS.

This Act does not limit the rights of discrimination victims under other Federal or State laws, including the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Education Amendments of 1972, Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. The obligations of this Act are additional to those of existing laws.
